editorialDecl.p: Edgeworth’s spelling and punctuation are retained in transcription, except where a word is split at the end of a line and the beginning of the next in a manuscript. The long s and ligatured forms are silently emended.

div.p:
3x I lost no time my dear Miss Edgeworth in complying with your wishes. But I regret to say that as yet I have not found Mr Edgeworths favour on the subject you mention. It must be in existence as I am sure I never would destroy any trace of a correspondence by which I esteem myself so much honoured. I only arrived in town last night having received your letter amongst my infant woods at Abbotsford and com mencedcommenced my researches this morning. My papers are but very imperfectly arranged considering that I was bred to business but in 1811 I perceive I had been already favoured with several letters from the late regretted Mr. E threeof which I inclose for the chance of their containing some thingsomething interesting to your present labours of love. The letter concern ingconcerning Darwin must I think be among a mass of papers relating to Miss Sewards poems which I will make a thorough search amongst as soon as may be. I assure you dear Madam there is no person in the world of literature for whose name I have more sincere respect or in whose regard I esteem myself more highly honoured, or whom I would have more pleasure in obliging. You have had a merit transcend denttranscendent in my eyes of raising your national character in the scale of public estimation and making the men of the British empire acquainted with the peculiar and interesting character of a people too long neglec -tedneglected and too severely oppressed. Public opinion though a slow is at length a sure rebuffer of wrongs and when this in respect to Ireland you have produced a strong and abiding affect and I trust that notwithstanding all the unfavourable circumstances which seem fated to restart the amelioration of Ireland I cannot help thinking that writings which back its natives their force and their weakness and shew to their fellow subjects there that value and worth must prepare both for a gradual but happy change. I do not rate the un -knownunknown author of our Scottish tales so high as to place him in the same rank either of Morel or utilityand yet I think highly of many of his works and expect to be gratified by those which are still promised from the same abundant and concealed source. I do assure you
I am quite an impartial judge upon the occasion & that you do me too much honour in supposing that I have any interest in these nar -rativesnarratives. The whole story told (as Miss Baillie informed me) by a Sir somebody Gordon about my having intimated to him any acquiescence in the report of my being the author of Antiquary is so absolutely false that I do not even know such a person I did know Sir Alis[superscript]t[/superscript]. Gordon who fell gloriously at Waterloo & I do know Sir Alexander Gordon of [unclear]Hilvenum[/unclear] but no other of the name. So if the Knight swears by his honour that the pancakes are naught do you eat the pan cakespancakes tout de meme & do not rashly suppose the Chevalier forsworn if you should find them very good. All this however I wrote to M[superscript]rs[/superscript] Baillie I should rather say to our dear Joanna whose talents and [unclear]heart[/unclear] you I know hold as highly as I do; so that I suppose she has already written to you on that subject. [paragraph ends]
Abbotsford 16 May It was destined I was not to find the letter until I returned hither for an unfortunate partiality for little cabinets and great cabinets and all sort of concealments and pigeon-holes holes makes it very difficult for me to know where any particular paper may happen to be [unclear][/unclear] I regret that the delay this has occasioned may make me seem what I would most unwillingly be thought slack or careless in complying with your request The letter contains an excellent and animated defence of D[superscript]r[/superscript] Darwin written with the spirit and feeling which your late respected relative was most likely to have exerted in behalf of a freind. Still however it does not appear to me to shake the powerful evidence that the lines in dispute were claimed by Miss Seward during Doctor Darwins lifetime and pub lished as hers and with her name. After all I do not think the verses very much were worth struggling about. But the liberality of the letter does great honour (like everything thing he did) to Mr. E.s memory. I found in the same drawer a letter of my own to Mr. Edgeworth begun after my release from France and never finished: a memorial among too many others how often I am misled by an unfortunate habit of procrastination into beco ming indifferent to the kindness of my best friends. Latterly indeed that as for the last twelve months I have had very indifferent health to plead as an excuse for being an irregular correspondent. I begin within these two last months to feel like myself again so that I trust I shall not have that painful apology any longer.[paragraph ends]
[page 3]
I am much obliged to you for thinking favourably of my attempts in poetry They have one title to indulgent compassion which is that they are a sort of or- phans for whom their ostich-parent cares most exceedingly little. In the earlier part of my literary life partly from temper partly from principle having observed how very unhappy library persons are made (not to say ridiculous into the bar- gain) by pitching their thoughts and happiness upon popular fame that I resolved to avoid at least that frailty & think as little about my poems when committed to the public as I well could. It is only when you Miss Edgeworth or a few others whose talents & candour rank high with me are kind enough to say that you receive pleasure from these poems that I ever think of them with satisfaction or indeed [insertion]think of them[/insertion] at all. I have not read one of them since they were printed excepting last year the Lady of the Lake which I liked better than I expected but not well enough to induce me to go through the rest so I may truly say with I am afraid to think of what I've done Macbeth I am afraid to think of what I've done Look out again I dare not - This much of Macbeth I recollect for that is not so easily forgotten that she was attempted from the existing person & character of a lady who is now no more. So that I am particularly flattered with your distinguishing it from the others which are in general mere shadows. [paragraph ends]
Thus far [underline]have I written amidst the clank and clang produced by [/underline] two noisy young bachelors my son and a cousin who are wearing out a rainy day by fencing with their naked broadswords to the imminent peril of their own heads to animate which conflict a probationary piper is excercizing a new & not over well tuned pair of bagpipes - all this being literally the case I really hardly know whether I am writing sense or nonsense - At least I must be comforted with the idea that my family is making some noise in the world [paragraph ends]
My rustic employments are so numerous and require so much of my own eye that I have no thoughts this season of quitting Scotland. If I can get away in winter I should like much to see Italy but I fear I cannot do this very conveniently. Ireland I trust I will one day visit but I must first get my dominions here put into some sort of orders I have of late been rather an extensive planter and incline in proportion to the extent of my property and these operations require a good deal of personal superintendence. [pagagraph ends]
A clergyman in your neighbourhood by name a gallant Gra- ham applied to me some time since wishing to connect himself with the border tribe of that name & willing to forward so reasonable & lau- dable a request I did some time since communicate to him what information occured to my recollection concerning these [unclear]worthies[/unclear]
He now writes to me that you wish to have a copy which (though I [unclear]should[/unclear] think it very uninteresting to you) is of course most humbly at your service. As however it was merely intended to gratify his own curiosity & by no times designed as a genealogical history for which I have neither time/ materials nor inclination - I hope the reverend gentleman will not take any means forgiving to the public such crude lucubrations, I do not know any thing of M[superscript]r [/superscript]Graham but I am always willing to return a civil answer to a gentleman of his profession who writes to me civilly; only I dont like to be hooked in for appearances on the public stage of which I have already made too many.
div.closer: Adieu my dear Miss Edgeworth My best wishes attend you in public & private & if we should never meet I trust you will still believe that you have not a more sincere friend and well wisher than Walter Scott. 15 May 1818
div.postscript:
I shall send these packet to my official friend Croker to be put under one of his omnipotent franks.
